items.title: Generative AI analyzes medical data faster than human research teams
items.summary: Researchers tested whether generative AI could handle complex medical datasets as well as human experts. In some cases, the AI matched or outperformed teams that had spent months building prediction models.
items.hook: FYI: AI stands for Artificial Intelligence, not Another Idli
items.question: Can you now summarize your conference recordings using AI?

items.title: James Webb Space Telescope captures strange magnetic forces warping Uranus
items.summary: For the first time, scientists have mapped Uranus‚Äôs upper atmosphere in three dimensions, tracking temperatures and charged particles up to 5,000 kilometers above the clouds. Webb‚Äôs sharp vision revealed glowing auroral bands and unexpected dark regions shaped by the planet‚Äôs wildly tilted magnetic field.

items.title: NASA‚Äôs Hubble spots nearly invisible ‚Äúghost galaxy‚Äù made of 99% dark matter
items.summary: Astronomers have uncovered one of the most mysterious galaxies ever found ‚Äî a dim, ghostly object called CDG-2 that is almost entirely made of dark matter. Located 300 million light-years away in the Perseus galaxy cluster, it was discovered in an unusual way: not by its stars, but by four tightly packed globular clusters acting like cosmic breadcrumbs.
items.hook: FYI: No one bends space more than you do
items.question: Are you the brightest object in the sky?

items.title: Scientists discover why high altitude protects against diabetes
items.summary: Living at high altitude appears to protect against diabetes, and scientists have finally discovered the reason. When oxygen levels drop, red blood cells switch into a new metabolic mode and absorb large amounts of glucose from the blood.
items.hook: FYI: You have 86 billion neurons. Activate atleast one now and then
items.question: What does XNA stand for again?

items.title: Scientists reveal why human language isn‚Äôt like computer code
items.summary: Human language may seem messy and inefficient compared to the ultra-compact strings of ones and zeros used by computers‚Äîbut our brains actually prefer it that way. New research reveals that while digital-style encoding could theoretically compress information more tightly, it would demand far more mental effort from both speaker and listener.

items.title: A spinning gyroscope could finally unlock ocean wave energy
items.summary: Ocean waves are a vast and steady source of renewable energy, but capturing their power efficiently has long frustrated engineers. A researcher at The University of Osaka has now explored a bold new approach: a gyroscopic wave energy converter that uses a spinning flywheel inside a floating structure to turn wave motion into electricity.
items.question: Is it okay for immigrants to litter?

items.title: ‚ÄúCeltic curse‚Äù hotspots found in Scotland and Ireland with 1 in 54 at risk
items.summary: Researchers have mapped the genetic risk of hemochromatosis across the UK and Ireland for the first time, uncovering striking hotspots in north-west Ireland and the Outer Hebrides. In some regions, around one in 60 people carry the high-risk gene variant linked to iron overload.

items.title: Common pneumonia bacterium may fuel Alzheimer‚Äôs disease
items.summary: A common bacterium best known for causing pneumonia and sinus infections may also play a surprising role in Alzheimer‚Äôs disease. Researchers found that Chlamydia pneumoniae can invade the retina and brain, where it sparks inflammation, nerve cell death, and the buildup of amyloid-beta‚Äîthe hallmark protein linked to Alzheimer‚Äôs.
